titleStmt.title: An ansvver to a proposition in order to the proposing of a Commonwealth or democracy. Proposed by friends to the Commonwealth by Mr. Harringtons consent; who is over-wise in his own conceit, that he propounds a Committee of Parliament, with above one hundred earls, nobles, members, gentlemen, and divines (named in his list) may dance attendance twice a week on his utopian excellency in the banquetting house at Whitehall or Painted Chamber, to hear and see his puppet-play of a new commonwealth: the very first view whereof he presumes will infatuate alldissenting [sic] parties, spectators, and our divided nations by their example into a Popish blinde obedience thereunto, upon his ipse dixit.
titleStmt.author: Prynne, William, 1600-1669.

Proposed by friends to the Commonwealth by Mr. Harringtons consent; who is over-wise in his own conceit, that he propounds a Committee of Parliament, with above one hundred earls, nobles, members, gentlemen, and divines (named in his list) may dance attendance twice a week on his utopian excellency in the banquetting house at Whitehall or Painted Chamber, to hear and see his puppet-play of a new commonwealth: the very first view whereof he presumes will infatuate alldissenting [sic] parties, spectators, and our divided nations by their example into a Popish blinde obedience thereunto, upon his ipse dixit.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ANSVVER TO A PROPOSITION In order to the propo≈øing of A Commonwealth or Democracy.

Propo≈øed by friends to the Commonwealth by Mr. Harringtons con≈øent; Who is ≈øo over-wi≈øe in his own conceit, that he propounds a Committee of Parliament, with above one hundred Earls, Nobles, Members, Gentlemen, and Divines (named in his li≈øt) may dance attendance twice a week on his Utopian Excellency in the Banquetting Hou≈øe at Whitehall or Painted Chamber, to hear and ≈øee his Puppet-play of a new Commonwealth: the very fir≈øt view whereof the pre≈øumes will infatuate all di≈ø≈øenting parties, ≈øpectators, and our divided Nations by their example into a Popi≈øh blinde obedience thereunto, upon his Ip≈øe dixit.
div.q: A whip for a Hor≈øe, a bridle for an A≈øs, and a rod for the Fools back. An≈øwer a Fool according to his Folly, le≈øt he be wi≈øe in his own conceit. See≈øt thou a man wi≈øe in his own conceit, there is more hope of a Fool, than of him.

div.head: A PROPOSITION In order to the propo≈øing of a Commonwealth or Democracy.
div.p: IF the Parliament ≈øhall be plea≈øed to appoint a Committee to receive Mr. Harringtons Propo≈øitions for ≈øetling the Government of this Commonwealth; it is humbly propo≈øed that unto the Committee of the Hou≈øe may be added

That this Committee ≈øit Tue≈ødayes and Fridayes, by three of the clock afternoon, in the Banqueting
hou≈øe, Court of Reque≈øts, or painted Chamber, the doors being open, and the Room well fitted for all Comers: and that Mr. Harrington having propo≈øed by appointment of the Parliament, ≈øuch others may propo≈øe as ≈øhall have the leave of the Parliament.
This by friends to the Commonwealth is propo≈øed with Mr. Harrington's con≈øent.

div.head: The Rea≈øons for this Propo≈øition are the≈øe:
div.p: It is the faire≈øt way of Propo≈øing a Government, that it be fir≈øt propo≈øed to conviction, before it be impo≈øed by power.
The Per≈øons herein nominated being convinced, it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have an healing influence upon all the Parties, degrees or qualities in this devided Nation.

div.head: THE ANSWER.
It is the de≈øire of our three divided Nations;
div.p: THat there be no Committee appointed by tho≈øe Commoners now ≈øitting to receive Mr. Harringtons Propo≈øitions for ≈øetling our old Kingly Government in his new way of a Commonwealth, till the Hou≈øe of Peers, and the ≈øecluded Members of the Commons Hou≈øe who ≈øate in Parliament till December 6. 1648. be permitted freely to fit, debate, and vote in Parliament, according to the Statute of 17 Caroli, c. 7. by which the pre≈øent Conventicle pretends to ≈øit.

That this being done, a Committee of both Hou≈øes may be appointed to receive Mr. Harringtons propo≈øitions. And that the per≈øons named in Mr. Harringtons li≈øt who are no M ‚Ä¢ mbers, with ≈øuch other wi≈øe men as Mr. Harrington and the friends to his propounded Commonwealth ≈øhall nominate, may have libertie to propo≈øe to the ≈øaid Committee what Mr. Harrington and they ≈øhall think fit in relation to the forming and erecting of the ≈øame.

That to the end the ≈øaid Mr. Harrington and his friends may in their propo≈øals be kept within the bounds of ≈øobrietie and moderation, according to the antient Law of Charondas, the Law-giver of the Athenians, (the fir≈øt erectors of Commonwealths,) Mr. Harrington and his friends may all come to the ≈øaid Committee with Ropes about their necks, and in ca≈øe they ≈øhall not convince the ≈øaid Committee (and Parliament) that their new Commonwealth is better, ≈øafer, and more profitable for the Engli≈øh Nation, than their old legal hereditarie Kingly Governusent, that then they ≈øhall forthwith by ≈øentence of Parliament be carried to Tyburne, and undergoe the penaltie of Charondas Law, to be hanged up by the neck as Traitors and ≈øeditious Per≈øons till they be dead.

But if their propo≈øals take effect: That then Mr. Harrington for his rare invention and extraordinarie good ≈øervice in minting a New Commonwealth, ≈øhall have the monopoly of coyning all new Harringtons, alias bra≈øs farthings, which ≈øhall henceforth pa≈øs for the onely coin of his new copper Commonwealth, Gold and ≈øilver which are Royal mines & metals annexed to the Imperial Crown of the Realm) being as incon≈øi≈øtent with his New Commonwealth, (which hath ≈øwallowed them all up) as King≈øhip, and therefore to be bani≈øhed with it.

The Committee is de≈øired to ≈øit every afternoon in the weeke by two of the clock at the Se≈ø≈øions hou≈øe in the Old Baily, or rather in the old Kings Bench Court in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, being places open to all Commers, and ≈øitted for that end, without further charge to the poor Commonwealth: That ≈øo Mr. Harrington and his friends may not be delayed from receiving a de≈øerved execution, or glorious reward.
This by the Generality of our 3 Nations friends to our Antient Monarchy is propo≈øed, and they hope to have Mr. Harringtons po≈øt-con≈øent thereto.

div.head: The Rea≈øons for this An≈øwer to the Propo≈øition are the≈øe:
div.p:
1. It is the faire≈øt way of altering our antient Kingly Government, and Parliament, that they be fir≈øt legally impeached and condemned to conviction before they be injuriou≈øly ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by armed power. Therefore M. Harrington mu≈øt fir≈øt an≈øwer M Wren & M. Pryns rea≈øons in his new publi≈øhed True and perfect Narrative; for the re≈øtitution of our old hereditarie Kings & King≈øhip, as the be≈øt of Governments, before he propound his New
∆≤topian Republike, to thru≈øt them out of their long-enjoyed po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

2. That Mr. Harrington and his friends being convinced of the illegality of the ≈øaid Commonwealth, and the dangerous con≈øequence of propo≈øing ≈øuch a ≈øeditious
novelties, again≈øt our old King≈øhip and Kingdomes, and duely executed according to Charondas law, it mu≈øt needes have a healing influence upon all the parties, degrees or qualities in the≈øe divided nations; ≈øince the exemplary execution of ≈øuch leading Innovators wil ≈øo terrifie all others that they will not dare mutter one word for the future again≈øt our antient fundamental government by King, Lords and Commons; which they are all obliged to maintain by ≈øacred Oaths and Covenants.

3. All the three Nations will Judge Mr. Harrington and his Republican friends are in good earne≈øt for the Government of Oceana, and as Valiant as Sir John Harringtons Ajax, when they ≈øhall ≈øo fairely adventure a voyage to Tyburne to introduce it.

Re≈øolved upon the Que≈øtion, (on Mr. Harringtons friends Petition) that Dr. Chamberlain ≈øhall attend him during all the time of his travel with his Gigantick Commonwealth, le≈øt it ≈øhould mi≈øcarry, and be ≈øtrangled in its birth: That if the orifice of his Brain or Womb be ≈øo narrow that the Doctors hands cannot u≈øher it into the world without ≈øuffocation, that then (Cae≈øar-like) the General Councel of Officers of the Army, ≈øhall violently cut it out of his Womb with their ≈øwords, rather then it ≈øhould be ≈øtill born, though with the Parents death: That if it be live-born, it ≈øhall not be chri≈øtened, till it be able to render an Account of its Faith to Cardinal Mazarin, Dr. Owen, Mr. Nye, and John Canne: That new dipped Col. Bennet, Col. Hew≈øon, Major Packer, and Lieut. Col. Allen, ≈øhall be Godfathers; the Whore of Rome, Mrs. Rolls, Mrs. Haggat, and Mal Cutpu ‚Ä¢ ≈øe Godmothers to it: That it ≈øhall be then called by the Fathers name, Harringtons (not Englands) Commonwealth, and bear his Arms in≈øtead of the ≈øuper≈øtitious red Engli≈øh Cro≈ø≈øe upon its Forhead: That in the mean time it ≈øhall be ≈øtrongly guarded night and day by the Keepers of the Liberties of England, and Col. Fleetwoods Regiment, le≈øt Dr. Chamberlains Denn of Thieves, or the Queen of Fayries, ≈øhould fteal it away out of its cradle, and put a mi≈øhapen Changeling without wit or rea≈øon, into its place, to the Parents di≈øhonour, and great di≈øappointment of the hopes and prayers of all the Publicans and Sinners, fal≈øly ≈øtiled, the godly people, and Saints of the 3. Nations, who rather de≈øire to enjoy a ≈øhare in the Commonwealth and Crown lands of England, Scotland and Ireland, than in the Kingdom and Crown of Glory in Heaven, Bonum quo communius eo melius, being a ≈øure principle, and the chief corner-≈øtone on which they intend to build their New Commonwealth, having little private wealth of their own, except Bra≈øs Harringtons, to inherit.
